title: What would happen if the Sun was moved 2 cm closer to Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: It probably just happened. And then in the opposite direction. First, you have to define what is “closer”. I mean as the Earth rotates, parts of it get closer to the Sun, others further way, in part because the surface of the Earth is obviously not perfectly smooth. Heck, if you live in a two story house, you can easily get close to 9′ closer just by walking up the stairs. If you want to get 2cm, stand on a thick book. In addition, I believe the Sun pulses in size larger than 2cm. And as others, our orbit is far from circular. Right now we’re heading closer to the Sun on average and perihelion will occur in January around the 3rd. We’ll be about 91.4 million miles from the Sun. (Yes for folks in the Northern hemisphere, believe it or not, we’re closest to the Sun in the winter!) About 6 months later we’ll be at aphelion when we’ll be about 94.5 million miles from the Sun. So 2cm… is nothing.

Nothing. The Sun already moves 2cm closer to the Earth, and 2cm farther from the Earth, on a regular basis. In actuality, the Earth doesn’t go around the Sun in a perfect circle. Forget 2cm. The Earth is about 91 million miles away from the Sun in January and 94.5 million miles away from the Sun in July. We shift more than 2cm closer or farther from the Sun perhaps as quickly as every minute. That’s vastly more than 2cm. We shift more than 2cm closer or farther from the Sun perhaps as quickly as every minute. Also, the Sun is a gas ball, not a solid object. Its ebbs and flows are also hugely greater than 2cm each day.

Absolutely nothing. The sun is already closer to Earth every year (and farther away) because the orbit of earth is not perfectly circular. At perihelion (when the Earth is closest to the sun) we are at a distance of about 91,398,199 miles (147,091,144 kilometers). At aphelion (when we are farthest) we are at 94,507,635 miles (152,095,295 km). Note the distance is a LOT more than 2cm! As it happens it does mean there is a slight difference in the length of seasons. Winters are five days shorter than summer in the Northern Hemisphere, while summers are five days shorter than winter in the Southern Hemisphere. But temperature wise the difference is hardly noticeable — the effect of land and water distribution is much greater.

Nothing. The Earth's orbit regularly moves considerably more than only 2 cm. Earth is at an average distance of 149.07 million km, but at perihelion (closest) we are 147.5 million km away (~4th January), while at aphelion (furthest) we are 153.6 million km away (~4th July). Looked at against these figures, your 2 cm measurement is vanishingly small.

It is interesting that this question uses the earth as the fixed reference for the distance between the sun and the earth and that if this distance changed, it would be as a result of the sun moving. I suspect that the questioner’s understanding of cosmology is based on 16th century beliefs rather than any rational thinking.
